name: Kepler-82
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-82 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-82 is a star with 0.91 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.9 times its radius. It is located 3026.6298332 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-82 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-82 system

Kepler-82 b

Kepler-82 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-82 b is 12.15 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-82 b is 4.07 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-82 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-82 c

Kepler-82 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The mass of Kepler-82 c is 13.9 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-82 c is 5.34 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-82 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-82 d

Kepler-82 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The radius of Kepler-82 d is 1.77 that of Earth.


Kepler-82 e

Kepler-82 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the Transit method. The radius of Kepler-82 e is 2.47 that of Earth.


Kepler-82 f

Kepler-82 f was discovered by the KOINet observatory using the Transit Timing Variations method. The mass of Kepler-82 f is 20.9 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-82 f is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-82, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
